results.headline: Review: ‘Eli Roth Presents the Stranger,’ a Tale Steeped in Blood
results.summary_short: Guillermo Amoedo’s movie concerns an outsider with a strange but beneficial affliction.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Stranger

results.headline: Review: ‘An Open Secret’ Spotlights Child Sexual Abuse in Hollywood
results.summary_short: In this documentary, directed by Amy Berg, former child actors recount the manipulations, cover-ups and exploitations they encountered in the entertainment industry.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An Open Secret

results.display_title: 2015 Sundance Film Festival Short Film Tour
results.headline: Review: Award-Winning Short Films From Sundance
results.summary_short: Four of the six films were written and directed by women, including the lone documentary, “The Face of Ukraine: Casting Oksana Baiul.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 2015 Sundance Film Festival Short Film Tour

results.headline: Review: ‘Testament of Youth’ Recalls the Great War With Little Nostalgia
results.summary_short: Adapted from Vera Brittain’s antiwar memoir, the film, which stars Alicia Vikander, describes battlefield devastation and damage that returned home.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Testament of Youth

results.headline: Review: ‘Love & Mercy’ Gets Inside Brian Wilson’s Head
results.summary_short: In Bill Pohlad’s Beach Boys biopic, Paul Dano plays Mr. Wilson in the 1960s, making “Pet Sounds,” and John Cusack plays him in the 1980s, making peace.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love & Mercy

results.headline: Review: ‘Insidious: Chapter 3’ Keeps a Franchise Rolling
results.summary_short: In this prequel to the original movie, directed by Leigh Whannell, a teenager enlists ghost hunters to try to connect with her dead mother.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Insidious: Chapter 3

results.headline: Review: ‘Wild Horses,’ a Film by and Starring Robert Duvall
results.summary_short: This melodrama, Mr. Duvall’s first directorial effort since “Assassination Tango” in 2003, also stars James Franco and Josh Hartnett.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wild Horses

results.headline: Review: ‘The Nightmare,’ Rodney Ascher’s Look at Sleep Paralysis
results.summary_short: Mr. Ascher uses re-enactments to help tell the stories of eight people with this disorder.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Nightmare

results.headline: Review: In ‘We Are Still Here,’ Ghostly Inhabitants Can Be the Toughest to Evict
results.summary_short: A couple’s move into an isolated handyman special built in 1859 is not quite the fresh start they were seeking.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are Still Here

results.headline: Review: In ‘United Passions,’ a Fictionalized FIFA, Underwritten by the Soccer Group
results.summary_short: While the soccer world is exploding with arrests and corruption charges, its governing body has released a dramatization of its history.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of United Passions

results.headline: Review: In ‘Spy,’ Melissa McCarthy Is a C.I.A. Drudge Who Goes Rogue
results.summary_short: Ms. McCarthy leads a starry cast in this action-comedy about an intelligence officer who proves her mettle in heroic and ridiculous ways.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spy

results.headline: Review: In ‘Patch Town,’ Animated Toys Work the Factory Line
results.summary_short: The director Craig Goodwill’s musical fairy tale, inspired by Eastern European folklore, features vivified toys that revolt against an unscrupulous corporate overlord.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Patch Town

results.headline: Review: In ‘Charlie’s Country,’ a Refugee in His Homeland
results.summary_short: The Aboriginal star David Gulpilil plays the title character in Rolf de Heer’s film about a man who feels out of place in his own country.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Charlie's Country

results.headline: Review: ‘Hungry Hearts,’ a Drama About Love and Obsession
results.summary_short: Saverio Costanzo’s film stars Adam Driver and Alba Rohrwacher as a New York couple whose relationship takes a dark turn after the birth of their baby.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hungry Hearts

results.headline: Review: ‘Freedom’ Stars Cuba Gooding Jr. as a Slave Fleeing to Canada
results.summary_short: Peter Cousens’s film follows two narratives: one set in Virginia and points north in 1856, the other on a trans-Atlantic slave ship in 1748.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Freedom

results.headline: Review: ‘Doomsdays,’ a Jaunt Into Strangers’ Homes in the Catskills
results.summary_short: Two vagabonds go on a Catskills adventure in this film from Eddie Mullins.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Doomsdays

results.headline: Review: ‘Every Last Child,’ a Front-Line View of the Polio Crisis in Pakistan
results.summary_short: Tom Roberts’s documentary examines the struggles of health workers in Pakistan to vaccinate children against polio in the face of mistrust and Taliban attacks.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Every Last Child

results.display_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence
results.headline: Review: ‘A Pigeon Sat on a Branch,’ Roy Andersson’s Rumination on Life
results.summary_short: Mr. Andersson’s signature style as a writer and director comes through in “A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence.”

results.headline: Review: ‘Entourage,’ the Screen Is Bigger, but Nothing Is Better
results.summary_short: By the time the show reached the end of its HBO run in 2011, it had grown staler than last night’s Axe body spray. The passing of a few more years has not improved the aroma.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Entourage

results.headline: Review: ‘Uncertain Terms’ Enters a Home for Pregnant Young Women
results.summary_short: In this film by Nathan Silver, an unhappily married handyman is dropped into an emotional maelstrom.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Uncertain Terms
